documentType: Bureau of Prisons psychology services records
summary: This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service records for inmate Jeffrey Edward Epstein, created shortly after his arrest in July 2019. It includes an initial intake screening, a risk of sexual abusiveness assessment, administrative notes, and a suicide risk assessment. The records detail his mental health evaluation, his denial of any mental health issues or suicidal ideation, and the institution's precautionary measures due to his high-profile case. This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychological assessments and clinical notes for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, conducted on July 9-10, 2019, following his return from a court proceeding. The assessments evaluate his suicide risk, mental status, and housing needs, concluding he is at low acute risk with no suicidality, and detail his requests and demeanor while on psychological observation. A series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service records documenting Jeffrey Epstein's mental health status and incidents while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York in July 2019. The records include clinical contacts, administrative notes, a Special Housing Unit (SHU) review, and detailed reports on a suicide watch incident on July 23, 2019, where Epstein was found with a string around his neck. This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology services clinical contact notes for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 25-30, 2019, while he was on psychological observation at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The notes detail his mental status, complaints about Special Housing Unit (SHU) conditions, his inability to recall how he sustained neck injuries, and his interactions with staff and attorneys. This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service reports and a memorandum concerning Jeffrey Epstein's mental health and disciplinary status while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York in July and August 2019. It includes competency evaluations, suicide risk assessments, clinical contacts, and a timeline of activities following his death. The reports consistently find Epstein competent for disciplinary proceedings and at low risk for suicide, despite an incident involving a string around his neck.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The subject of all psychological evaluations, disciplinary reports, and suicide risk assessments while incarcerated at MCC New York. He is assessed for competency following an incident report for tattooing/self-mutilation and repeatedly evaluated for suicide risk.

persons.name: PsyD/PhD
persons.context: A Bureau of Prisons psychologist who conducted the initial intake screening and risk of sexual abusiveness assessment for inmate Epstein on July 8, 2019.

persons.name: PhD/Chief Psychologist
persons.context: A Bureau of Prisons chief psychologist who consulted with Dr. Central Office, issued administrative notes regarding suicide risk, and conducted the suicide risk assessment for inmate Epstein on July 9-10, 2019.

persons.name: Dr. Central Office
persons.context: A psychologist from the BOP Central Office who was consulted by the chief psychologist regarding inmate Epstein's risk factors for suicidality.

persons.name: PsyD
persons.context: Primary author/provider of multiple psychology reports, including the Institution Disciplinary Process Report and Suicide Risk Assessments for Epstein in late July and early August 2019.

persons.name: Ph.D.
persons.context: A psychologist who conducted the assessment to step Epstein down from Suicide Watch to Psychological Observation on July 24, 2019, and documented his account of the string incident and his cellmate.

persons.name: Dr.
persons.context: Referenced as the author of a prior Suicide Risk Assessment on July 9, 2019, which is summarized in the later report.

persons.name: Operations Lt.
persons.context: Notified the on-call psychologist in the early hours of July 23, 2019, that Epstein was being placed on Suicide Watch.

persons.name: Captain
persons.context: Notified by the assessing psychologist about a notation in the Staff Suicide Watch Log where Epstein allegedly told staff his cellmate tried to kill him; the Captain stated they were already aware.

persons.name: SHU lieutenant
persons.context: Informed by a psychologist about Epstein's complaints regarding missing items (soap, spoon, phone calls); said he would ensure they were provided.

persons.name: Nick
persons.context: Epstein's old cellmate in SHU. Epstein expressed a desire to speak with him to see if he could provide information about the incident that caused the marks on Epstein's neck.

persons.name: Nurse Columbo
persons.context: A medical nurse who examined Epstein for complaints of numbness in his right arm and neck on July 28, 2019.

persons.name: Proto
persons.context: Referred inmate Epstein for a competency evaluation regarding the disciplinary process for an incident report.

persons.name: Dr. Ig
persons.context: Authored a Suicide Risk Assessment for Epstein on July 9, 2019, noting Epstein denied any mental health history or symptoms.

persons.name: RIM PsyD/DAPC
persons.context: Conducted a clinical contact/follow-up session with Epstein on July 31, 2019, after he was removed from Psychological Observation.

persons.name: IMIIMPsyD
persons.context: Completed a Suicide Risk Assessment for Epstein on August 1, 2019.

persons.name: EM PsyD
persons.context: Provider listed for an assessment on August 1, 2019.

persons.name: MI PsyD
persons.context: Provider listed as generating a Suicide Risk Assessment report on August 1, 2019.

persons.name: MIIMEL PhD/Chief
persons.context: Conducted a follow-up session with Epstein in SHU on August 8, 2019, and provided supportive interventions.

persons.name: Warden
persons.context: Recipient of memoranda and meetings with psychology staff regarding Epstein and the aftermath of his death.

persons.name: AWE
persons.context: Spoken to on August 10, 2019, and asked to print and summarize BEMR/PDS notes following Epstein's suicide.

persons.name: Dila
persons.context: Spoken to on August 10, 2019.

persons.name: Dr. Illa
persons.context: Spoken with on August 10, 2019, and noted as coming to the institution on Monday.

connections.description: The chief psychologist conducted a suicide risk assessment and psychological observation of inmate Epstein.
The psychologist conducted the initial intake screening and risk of sexual abusiveness assessment for inmate Epstein.
The chief psychologist consulted with Dr. Central Office regarding inmate Epstein's risk factors for suicidality.
The psychologist assessed Epstein's mental status, suicide risk, and provided clinical intervention and coping strategies.
Clinical relationship where the psychologist provides mental health assessments and interventions to inmate Epstein.
Clinical relationship where the psychologist assesses Epstein after the suicide watch incident.
Clinical relationship where the psychologist evaluates Epstein for stepping down from suicide watch and documents his account of the cellmate incident.
Epstein reported his cellmate was agitated, called him a 'pedophile,' and was reading a newspaper article about him. Epstein also allegedly told staff his cellmate tried to kill him.
The psychologist notified the Captain about the discrepancy in Epstein's account (allegedly telling staff his cellmate tried to kill him).
Clinical therapeutic relationship between inmate and prison psychologist. Epstein was assessed and provided interventions by the Chief Psychologist.
Clinical therapeutic relationship between inmate and prison psychologist. The PsyD conducted assessments and provided coping resources.
Former cellmates in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). Epstein wanted to contact Nick to potentially learn about the incident that caused his neck injuries.
Patient-medical provider relationship. Nurse Columbo addressed Epstein's physical complaints of numbness.
Unit Manager Proto referred inmate Epstein for a competency evaluation regarding the disciplinary process.
Psychologist PsyD conducted multiple clinical evaluations, competency assessments, and suicide risk assessments for inmate Epstein.
The Chief Psychologist conducted a follow-up clinical session with Epstein in SHU on August 8, 2019.

events.title: Epstein's Initial Intake Screening
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes a psychology services intake screening at MCC-NY upon arrival. He denies any history of mental health treatment or symptoms.

events.title: Risk of Sexual Abusiveness Assessment
events.description: Psychology services assess Epstein's risk for sexual abusiveness based on his history of prior sexual abuse perpetration in the community. He is judged to be at low risk but declines sex offender treatment programming.

events.title: Court Proceeding and Precautionary Measures
events.description: Epstein attends a court proceeding. Due to his high-profile case and potential for bad legal news, the psychology department instructs staff to notify them immediately upon his return for a suicide risk assessment.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Epstein is interviewed for a suicide risk assessment after being placed on precautionary psychological observation. He denies any suicidal ideation and is found to have a low overall acute suicide risk.

events.title: Epstein's Court Proceeding
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein returned from a court proceeding in the evening, which may have given him bad news regarding his legal situation, prompting a precautionary psychological observation.

events.title: Clinical Intervention Session
events.description: Epstein was seen for a psychological observation contact, expressed various concerns and requests about housing and conditions, and was provided supportive intervention.

events.title: Upcoming Bail Hearing
events.description: Epstein reported he was going to have a bail hearing on Monday (July 15, 2019) and believed he was going to be released from jail.

events.title: Epstein placed on Suicide Watch after string incident
events.description: At about 2 AM, Epstein was placed on Suicide Watch after being found in his SHU cell with a string loosely hanging around his neck. He had a circular line around the base of his neck. He claimed no memory of the event.

events.title: Epstein stepped down from Suicide Watch
events.description: After assessment, Epstein was removed from Suicide Watch and stepped down to Psychological Observation. He adamantly denied suicidality, expressed future plans for his legal case, and described having a 'wonderful life.'

events.title: Epstein placed in SHU (Administrative Detention)
events.description: Epstein was placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) under administrative detention status.

events.title: Epstein's psychological observation follow-up
events.description: Epstein was seen for a psychological observation follow-up. He reported concerns about incarceration conditions (cold cell, missing property/medication, orange jumpsuit) but denied suicidal ideation.

events.title: Epstein reports missing items in SHU
events.description: Epstein reported not receiving a spoon, soap, or promised phone calls in SHU. Staff later stated they witnessed him receive two phone calls.

events.title: Initial Psychological Observation Session
events.description: Epstein is seen on psychological observation in the hospital area. He is in good spirits but cannot remember how he received marks around his neck. He complains about SHU conditions and denies suicidality.

events.title: Follow-up Psychological Session
events.description: Epstein is seen again on observation. He showers for a legal visit, cracks jokes, and continues to complain about SHU and legal visit procedures. He again states he has no memory of the neck injury event and asks to speak with his old cellmate Nick.

events.title: Continued Observation and Complaints
events.description: Epstein is interviewed by a PsyD. He reports anxiety about returning to SHU, sleep deprivation due to noise, and feeling dehydrated due to limited bathroom breaks during legal visits. He denies suicidal ideation.

events.title: Epstein Reports Aversive Incident and Numbness
events.description: Epstein reports a toilet flushing continuously for 45 minutes, which he found extremely aversive and which agitated him for hours. He also complains of numbness in his right arm and neck, leading to a medical consultation with Nurse Columbo.

events.title: Epstein Attributes Memory Loss to Sleep Apnea
events.description: Epstein suggests his memory impairment regarding the neck injury may be due to sleep apnea. He is expecting his CPAP machine and requests to stay in the hospital area for safety, but is told he will return to SHU.

events.title: Psychological Observation Discontinued
events.description: Epstein is seen for a final observation session. He discusses sleep issues and SHU noise. The Chief Psychologist is consulted, and psychological observation is formally discontinued. Plans are made for follow-up in SHU.

events.title: Epstein Found with String Around Neck
events.description: Inmate Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck. He stated he did not remember how it got there, leading to an incident report for tattooing/self-mutilation.

events.title: Competency Evaluation Completed
events.description: A psychology services report determined inmate Epstein was COMPETENT to proceed with the disciplinary process regarding the July 23 incident.

events.title: Clinical Follow-Up After Removal from Observation
events.description: Epstein was seen for a follow-up after being removed from Psychological Observation. He reported going to court for a status hearing and was adjusting back to SHU.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment After Marshals' Form
events.description: A Suicide Risk Assessment was conducted after US Marshals had Epstein sign a form noting 'suicidal tendencies' upon his return from court. The assessment found his overall acute suicide risk to be Low.

events.title: Final Documented Clinical Session
events.description: Epstein was seen for a follow-up session in SHU. He reported feeling okay, wanting to go to general population, and denied any suicidal ideation or mental health symptoms.

events.title: Epstein's Suicide Reported
events.description: A timeline entry notes being contacted to report to the institution and informed that 'Mr. Epstein committed suicide.' Psychology staff then engaged in various tasks including printing notes and meeting with the warden.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC-NY / NYM)
Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York, New York (MCC NYM)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein, during his July 2019 intake, denied any history of mental health treatment, substance abuse, or being a victim of physical/sexual abuse.
Epstein was assessed as being at 'low risk of abusiveness' for sexual behavior within the prison but had a documented history of prior sexual abuse perpetration in the community.

BOP psychology staff identified multiple risk factors for suicidality, including his high-profile case, sex trafficking charges, pre-trial status, and a recent court proceeding, leading to precautionary psychological observation.

Epstein reported during his suicide risk assessment that he had served time previously in Palm Beach County jail on soliciting prostitution charges and was currently charged with federal sex trafficking.

The psychological evaluations concluded Epstein had no psychological diagnosis, was classified as CARE1-MH (no need for regular mental health intervention), and was found to have a low acute suicide risk with numerous protective factors.
On July 9, 2019, a BOP psychologist assessed Jeffrey Epstein as having a 'Low' acute suicide risk and 'Absent' chronic suicide risk, with no need for a suicide watch.

Epstein explicitly and adamantly denied any past or present suicidal ideation, intention, or plan during the assessment, and was described as future-oriented with a positive outlook on his legal case.

Epstein was placed on precautionary psychological observation after returning from court on July 8, 2019, due to risk factors including his high-profile case, sex trafficking charges, and pre-trial status.
Epstein reported his only family was his brother, with whom he did not have a relationship, and cited a support system of friends and associates in the community.
During a clinical session on July 10, 2019, Epstein made numerous requests regarding housing, medication, uniforms, and property, and was psychologically stable with no acute distress.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck, resulting in a circular mark, and was placed on Suicide Watch.
Epstein claimed no memory of the string incident. However, a Staff Suicide Watch Log noted he told staff his cellmate tried to kill him, a statement he did not repeat to the assessing psychologist.
Epstein reported his cellmate was agitated, called him a 'pedophile,' and was reading a newspaper article about him, which Epstein found disturbing.
Epstein consistently denied past and present suicidal ideation, intention, or plans, both before and after the July 23 incident, and was stepped down from Suicide Watch on July 24, 2019.
The psychological assessments identified static risk factors for Epstein including 'High Profile Crime,' 'Lack of family connections,' and 'Sex offender status.'
Jeffrey Epstein sustained unexplained marks and a scab around his neck while in the Special Housing Unit (SHU), but repeatedly claimed to have no memory of how the injuries occurred.
Epstein consistently denied any suicidal or self-harm ideation, stating he was 'a coward,' 'Jewish,' and too vested in fighting his legal case to harm himself.

Epstein expressed significant distress about conditions in the SHU, citing noise, smells, feeling punished, and restrictions, which he claimed prevented him from sleeping and working on his legal case.

Psychology staff kept Epstein on psychological observation 'in an abundance of caution' due to his vague account of the neck injury and adjustment concerns, but found no acute mental health symptoms precluding a return to SHU.
Epstein was actively engaged in legal visits with his attorneys throughout the observation period and was described as animated, laughing, and joking during those visits.

On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck. He stated he did not remember how it happened, and it was unclear if he or someone else placed it there.

A Bureau of Prisons psychology report dated July 30, 2019, determined Epstein was COMPETENT to proceed with the disciplinary process related to the July 23 incident (charged with tattooing/self-mutilation).

Multiple suicide risk assessments between July 9 and August 8, 2019, consistently noted Epstein denied any past or present suicidal ideation, intention, or plan, and found his overall acute suicide risk to be Low.
A timeline entry for August 10, 2019, states staff were contacted and informed 'Mr. Epstein committed suicide,' triggering institutional response activities.

Psychology reports note Epstein identified protective factors against suicide, including his Jewish religion's stance against suicide, future plans, support from friends and lawyers, and a commitment to life.
